awd_titl_txt: "Advancing Students' Proof Practices in Mathematics through Inquiry, Reinvention, and Engagement"
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the NSF Improving Undergraduate STEM Education Program: Education and Human Resources (IUSE: EHR), this project aims to serve the national interest by improving undergraduate mathematics education.  It will do so by creating curriculum modules for a transition-to-proof course for both two-year and four-year institutions. The modules, grounded in inquiry-based instruction, will be developed through a collaboration between California State University Chico, Clackamas Community College, Michigan State University, Butte College, and Mount Hood Community College. The Teachers Development Group will provide expertise in developing pedagogical strategies for implementing the modules. The project will use established methods to create knowledge, as well as innovative tools that have potential to improve the quality of education experienced by mathematics students. Actively engaging students in learning through inquiry-based instruction may enhance the student learning experience in the transition to proofs.  This improvement may increase student entry into and persistence in proof-based mathematics courses, thus contributing to a mathematically sophisticated STEM workforce. The products created by the project will be freely available as web-based resources, such as an online Wiki-style textbook and web-based multimedia instructor supports.

The project seeks to draw on established design research methodology to develop inquiry-based curricular materials and a suite of resources designed to support instructors in taking on the challenges associated with ambitious student-centered pedagogy. Project deliverables will include a modular curriculum (for use in courses designed to help students transition to advanced proof-based mathematics), web-based instructor support materials, a Wiki-textbook template, and a professional development workshop. The project will be designed to create an ideal starting point for mathematics faculty to begin teaching with student-centered inquiry methods that are known to be more supportive of student success. The project will investigate how students can be supported in reinventing foundational topics in real analysis as well as how inquiry-based instruction can provide equitable outcomes. The project will also investigate the supports instructors need in implementing inquiry-based instruction. The project outcomes will be disseminated through a professional development workshop, an open-access repository, conference presentations, and publications. The NSF IUSE: EHR Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students. Through the Engaged Student Learning track, the program supports the creation, exploration, and implementation of promising practices and tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The I-USE Development and Implementation Level 2 project, Advancing Students' Proof Practices in Mathematics through Inquiry, Reinvention, and Engagement (ASPIRE in Math), was focused on improving “transition-to-proof” courses. These courses are intended to prepare students for the difficult transition from the computation-based mathematics courses that dominate the first two years of post-secondary mathematics to the proof-based courses that permeate the advanced mathematics coursework. 

 

The ASPIRE in Math project produced a collection of inquiry-based curriculum modules and a suite of instructor support resources designed for both the university and community college contexts. The instructional sequences engage students in the guided reinvention of fundamental concepts in group theory and/or introductory real analysis and then leverage these experiences to support students in developing knowledge and skills needed to succeed in proof-based mathematics courses.

 

Project deliverables included four new proof modules, Online Instructor Support Materials (OISM) website, an online Wiki-style textbook (Wiki-text), professional development workshops, and online self-guided professional development materials. Deliverables were developed using design research methodology that featured cycles of design-analyze-redesign. 

 

The project directly involved three community college and three university partners that implemented ASPIRE in Math materials. Additionally, approximately 30 different institutions were impacted through the participation of faculty in the professional development workshops. For the 2022 summer workshop, we invited applications from faculty across the United States. We received more than 50 applicants and were able to accommodate 28 participants. 

 

The COVID-19 pandemic presented challenges to the project but also opened up important opportunities. First, the team needed to do the work to adapt to remote synchronous learning which resulted in the creation of a number of digital resources as well as significant insight into how inquiry-based learning can be supported in an online learning environment. Second, the transition back to the physical classroom provided an opportunity to investigate the utility of transporting tools and strategies created for the remote environment into the physical classroom to improve student engagement and learning. For example, we were able to investigate the benefits of having students collaborate in-person using a shared Google Doc on iPads. 

 

The involvement of multiple instructors as different institutions working under different constraints, revealed a problem that subsequently led to a significant innovation. Early in the project, we found that we needed to create a custom set of curricular materials for each instructor based on their goals, needs, and constraints. After engaging in a few iterations of this kind of large-scale adaptation/refinement of the materials, we decided to build automatic curriculum customization into the OISM. This involved 1) developing a large collection of “building block” lessons and a set of viable ways to combine these into instructional sequences or courses, 2) programming a feature that could automatically populate an instructor’s version of the OISM with only the instructional sequence they want, and 3) building an interactive “catalog” that would support instructors in making an informed decision about the instructional sequence(s) they wanted. In the current version (as of 2024) instructors can choose between 32 different ASPIRE in Math instructional sequences that differ in terms of the content (group theory and/or real analysis), math practices emphasized (e.g. analyzing proofs or using formal math language), and the number of instructional hours needed.
